verses.text: Canst thou draw out leviathan with an hook ? or his tongue with a cord \add which\add* thou lettest down ?\f + \fr 41.1 \ft leviathan: probably an extinct animal of some kind\f*\f + \fr 41.1 \ft which…: Heb. which thou drownest?\f*
Canst thou put an hook into his nose ? or bore his jaw through with a thorn ?
Will he make many supplications unto thee? will he speak soft \add words\add* unto thee?
Will he make a covenant with thee? wilt thou take him for a servant for ever ?
Wilt thou play with him as \add with\add* a bird ? or wilt thou bind him for thy maidens ?
Shall the companions make a banquet of him? shall they part him among the merchants ?
Canst thou fill his skin with barbed irons ? or his head with fish spears ?
Lay thine hand upon him, remember the battle , do no more.
Behold, the hope of him is in vain : shall not \add one\add* be cast down even at the sight of him?
None \add is so\add* fierce that dare stir him up : who then is able to stand before me? \p
Who hath prevented me, that I should repay \add him? whatsoever is\add* under the whole heaven is mine.
I will not conceal his parts , nor his power , nor his comely proportion.
Who can discover the face of his garment ? \add or\add* who can come \add to him\add* with his double bridle ?\f + \fr 41.13 \ft with: or, within\f*
Who can open the doors of his face ? his teeth \add are\add* terrible round about.
\add His\add* scales \add are his\add* pride , shut up together \add as with\add* a close seal.\f + \fr 41.15 \ft scales: Heb. strong pieces of shields\f*
One is so near to another , that no air can come between them.
They are joined one to another , they stick together , that they cannot be sundered.
By his neesings a light doth shine , and his eyes \add are\add* like the eyelids of the morning.
Out of his mouth go burning lamps , \add and\add* sparks of fire leap out.
Out of his nostrils goeth smoke , as \add out\add* of a seething pot or caldron.
His breath kindleth coals , and a flame goeth out of his mouth.
In his neck remaineth strength , and sorrow is turned into joy before him.\f + \fr 41.22 \ft is turned into joy: Heb. rejoiceth\f*
The flakes of his flesh are joined together : they are firm in themselves; they cannot be moved.\f + \fr 41.23 \ft flakes: Heb. fallings\f*
His heart is as firm as a stone ; yea, as hard as a piece of the nether \add millstone\add*.
When he raiseth up himself, the mighty are afraid : by reason of breakings they purify themselves.
The sword of him that layeth at him cannot hold : the spear , the dart , nor the habergeon.\f + \fr 41.26 \ft habergeon: or, breastplate\f*
He esteemeth iron as straw , \add and\add* brass as rotten wood.
The arrow cannot make him flee : slingstones are turned with him into stubble.
Darts are counted as stubble : he laugheth at the shaking of a spear.
Sharp stones \add are\add* under him: he spreadeth sharp pointed things upon the mire.\f + \fr 41.30 \ft Sharp stones: Heb. Sharp pieces of potsherd\f*
He maketh the deep to boil like a pot : he maketh the sea like a pot of ointment.
He maketh a path to shine after him; \add one\add* would think the deep \add to be\add* hoary.
Upon earth there is not his like , who is made without fear.\f + \fr 41.33 \ft is made without fear: or, behave themselves without fear\f*
He beholdeth all high \add things:\add* he \add is\add* a king over all the children of pride.
